instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.P3V3SUS_EN: What is P3V3SUS_EN? P3V3SUS_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_SUS power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message:
Had a liquid spill exactly on <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7503</CAPACITOR>.

Since <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> is 8v and <CAPACITOR>C7503</CAPACITOR> is 5v, is it fair to guess a dead <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message: Also check clock / ROM area ( <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, Y1905, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> ), very common for 3437/00165 to suffer issues there due to liquid ingress (or even just literal bugs), especially if it got as far in on the board as <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message: You are guessing without taking any measurements?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 34743"]You are guessing without taking any measurements? [/QUOTE]

PPBus = 8.57v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 1.045v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42v

Investigating <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> first.


-- side note for later.
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> @
<RESISTOR>R1841</RESISTOR>::1 = 3.42v
<RESISTOR>R1841</RESISTOR>::2 = 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message:
There is no <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> why are we looking at <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>? This is something around the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> or a short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

Check traces around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and/or replace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 34814"]There is no <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> why are we looking at <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>? [/QUOTE]

Not specifically <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>, but <SIGNAL>3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL>.

[quote]
This is something around the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> or a short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

Check traces around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and/or replace.[/QUOTE]

The traces around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> are horrible but seem to beep out ok.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message: Replace 7501 and check traces while it's off, especially pin 23.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message: ::23 has continuity to <CAPACITOR>C7540</CAPACITOR> et al, but ::24 has nothing to <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message:
Got continuity back. Replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> with a new one.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> @<CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> is 0.9v now. Crappy soldering maybe?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power, green/orange light ok.
threads.message: I have no idea, you have your eyes on it. This problem is around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> for sure.
